Currently, only the governments of [[Turkey]] and [[Azerbaijan]] deny that there was an Armenian genocide, with their ally [[Pakistan]] not even recognizing [[Armenia]] as a country.{{Cite web | title = History News Network - Christopher Hitchens: Turkey Denies History | work = hnn.us | url = http://hnn.us/roundup/entries/125231.html }}{{Cite web | title = Радио Свобода: Наши гости: Факты и мнения | work = svoboda.org | url = http://archive.svoboda.org/programs/RT/2001/RT.021701.asp }}{{Cite news | title = Q&An Armenian 'genocide' | publisher = [[BBC]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6045182.stm | date = 12 October 2006 | access-date = 29 December 2006 }} Many other countries, most controversially the [[United States]] (pressured by the [[Turkish lobby in the United States|Turkish lobby]], [[Israel]], and, in the past, the [[Anti-Defamation League]]),[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/19/us/19genocide.html "Armenian Issue Presents a Dilemma for U.S. Jews"], ''[[The New York Times]]''[http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2013/04/25/the-1915-armenian-genocide-why-is-it-still-denied-by-turkey-and-the-u-s/ "The 1915 Armenian Genocide – Why Is It Still Denied By Turkey (And The U.S.)?"], ''[[TheBlaze]]''[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Politics-And-Diplomacy/Israel-and-the-Jewish-People-cant-ignore-the-Armenian-Holocaust-398053 "Israel and the Jewish People can't ignore the Armenian Holocaust"], ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''{{Cite web|url=http://armenianweekly.com/2016/05/16/adl-armenian-genocide-2016/|title=ADL’s Official Recognition of Armenian Genocide Ends Years-Long Controversy|last=Hairenik|date=2016-05-16|website=The Armenian Weekly|access-date=2017-04-24}} have deliberately avoided officially recognizing it as a genocide to avoid harming relations with Turkey. In 2016, however, Anti-Defamation League CEO Jonathan Greenblatt unequivocally acknowledged the veracity of the Armenian Genocide, and stated that the organization supports U.S. recognition.{{Cite web|url=https://www.adl.org/blog/adl-on-the-armenian-genocide|title=ADL on the Armenian Genocide|website=Anti-Defamation League|language=en|access-date=2017-04-24}} The Turkish government has spent millions of dollars on Washington [[Turkish lobby in the United States|lobbying]] over the past decade, much of it focused on the Armenian genocide issue,"[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/03/03/AR2010030303786.html Armenia-Turkey dispute over genocide label sets off lobbying frenzy]". ''The Washington Post''. 3 March 2010. and has in the past threatened politicians from other countries with strong retaliation to prevent them from using the word ''genocide''.[http://uk.businessinsider.com/erdogan-threatens-germany-over-armenian-genocide-2016-6 "Why the Armenian Genocide of 1915 could collapse the EU's refugee deal with Turkey today"], ''[[Business Insider]]''[http://asbarez.com/151353/turkey-threatens-to-abandon-europe-after-armenian-genocide-bill/ Turkey Threatens to Abandon Europe after Armenian Genocide Bill], ''[[Asbarez]]''[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-why-armenia-genocide-recognition-remains-a-tough-sell-20150426-story.html "Why Armenia Genocide recognition remains a tough sell"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' The Turkish Republic has also been accused of attempting to intimidate and silence foreign [[investigative journalist]]s and genocide scholars.{{cite book | last = Whitehorn | first = Alan | title = The Armenian Genocide : the essential reference guide | publisher = ABC-CLIO | location = Santa Barbara, California | year = 2015 | page = 27 | isbn = 1610696883 }}{{cite book | last = Bartrop | first = Paul | title = Modern genocide : the definitive resource and document collection | publisher = ABC-CLIO | location = Santa Barbara, California | year = 2015 | page = 135 | isbn = 1610693647 }} ==Terminology== According to historian [[Yair Auron]], "there can be no doubt about the fact of [Armenian] genocide itself. In this sense, the denial of the Armenian genocide is very similar to the denial of the Holocaust."[[Yair Auron]], ''The Banality of Indifference: Zionism and the Armenian Genocide''. Transaction Publishers, 2000, p. 53. {{ISBN|0-7658-0881-1}}. Of the notable scholars that dispute its designation, [[Bernard Lewis]], [[Stanford J. Shaw|Stanford Shaw]] and [[Guenter Lewy]] acknowledge the historical event and its implications but reject a genocidal intent in favor of "uniqueness" of the [[Holocaust]] as only true genocide.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} [[Justin McCarthy (American historian)|Justin McCarthy]], [[Heath W. Lowry|Heath Lowry]] and [[Eberhard Jäckel]] reject the designation altogether, and have met much criticism and accusations from other scholars as promoting Armenian Genocide denial.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} ===The term "genocide"=== The term "genocide" was coined by the Polish Jew [[Raphael Lemkin]] in 1943, who had escaped Nazi rule, although the full extent of [[the Holocaust]] was not yet known at the time. He later used it to describe what he had heard about the Armenian Genocide: in a 1949 CBS interview with Quincy Howe, Lemkin explained, "I became interested in genocide because it happened so many times. It happened to the Armenians, then after the Armenians, [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] took action."{{Cite news | title = A PBS Documentary Makes Its Case for the Armenian Genocide, With or Without a Debate | newspaper = The New York Times | year = 2006 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/featured_articles/20060419wednesday.html | access-date = 1 November 2011 }} ====Genocide convention==== Turkish denialists claim that the "intent to destroy" clause of the Genocide Convention has not been met, and that it is therefore not a genocide.{{Cite book | title = The Orly Trial, 19 February – 2 March 1985, Statement and Evidence Presented at the Trial | last = Soysal | first = Mumtaz | author-link = Mumtaz Soysal | year = 1985 | publisher = Ankara University, Faculty of Political Sciences | quote = But the third element is the most important: there has to be "an intent of destroying", in part or in whole the said group. This key-description helps to differentiate between genocide and other forms of homicide, which are the consequences of other motives such as in the case of wars, uprisings etc. Homicide becomes genocide when the latent or apparent intention of physical destruction is directed at members of any one of the national, ethnic, racial or religious groups simply because they happen to be members of that group. The concept of numbers only becomes significant when it can be taken as a sign of such an intention against the group. That is why, as Sartre said in speaking of genocide on the occasion of the Russell Tribunal on the Vietnam War, that one must study the facts objectively in order to prove if this intention exists, even in an implicit manner. }}{{elucidate|date=April 2014}} After vague claims made by a speaker from the United Kingdom, [[Geoffrey Robertson]], a noted British barrister and specialist in the field of human rights, observed that the British government refused to acknowledge the Armenian Genocide by saying that evidence for it was "not sufficiently unequivocal". He pointed out that this phrase 1) was an [[oxymoron]] and 2) represented an invented standard of proof. He explained: "There are only two standards of proof in UK law: the civil standard (on the balance of probabilities; i.e. more likely than not) and the criminal standard (beyond reasonable doubt)". He further observed that recent British governments have not taken into account that the terms used by the British government of the time in referring to 1915 entirely anticipated the modern definition of genocide and that the drafters of the Genocide Convention had 1915 in mind when drafting the new international crime.http://groong.usc.edu/Geoffrey-Robertson-QC-Genocide.pdf ===The term "deportation"=== Currently, regarding the activities performed under the [[Tehcir Law]] of May 1915, the [[Republic of Turkey]] rejects the use of the word "deportation" and "refugee". Turkey instead uses the words "relocation" and "immigrant", respectively. Turkey claims in its state-supported ''Views Against Genocide Allegations'' that all the destination regions were within the Ottoman Empire's borders, and that the Ottoman government recognized these "immigrants" as its citizens and took extensive measures to record the type, quantity, and value of their property, as well as the names of the owners and where they were sent.{{Cite web | title = Views Against Genocide Allegations | publisher = Republic of Turkey Ministry of Culture and Tourism | url = http://www.kultur.gov.tr/EN/BelgeGoster.aspx?17A16AE30572D313AAF6AA849816B2EF11C077A9979C33C4 | date = 12 October 2006 | access-date = 29 December 2006 }} ==Turkish government position== In 2016 Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]] said "Our attitude on the Armenian issue has been clear from the beginning. We will never accept the accusations of genocide". The [[Turkish government]] does not deny that many Armenians were killed by the [[Ottoman military]], but disputes the death toll, and emphasizes that there were deaths on both sides during [[World War I]].{{Cite web |website= Deutsche Welle (www.dw.com, "German wave") |title= Erdogan: Turkey will 'never accept' genocide charges {{!}} DW {{!}} 04.06.2016 |accessdate= 2018-02-07 |url= http://www.dw.com/en/erdogan-turkey-will-never-accept-genocide-charges/a-19307115}} Scholars give several reasons for the Turkish government's denial including the preservation of [[national identity]], but also territorial concerns (called "[[Treaty of Sèvres|Sevres Syndrome]]"). Turkey's territorial concerns are exacerbated by Armenia's refusal to recognize Turkey's eastern borders. Another reason is the demand for [[Armenian Genocide reparations|reparations]].{{Cite book| publisher = ABC-CLIO| isbn = 978-1-4408-3161-4| last1 = Tatz| first1 = Colin| last2 = Higgins| first2 = Winton| title = The Magnitude of Genocide| date = 2016-03-14}} Armenian diaspora groups have in recent years become more focused on financial reparations. The Armenian Genocide Reparations Study Group has released a study that was partly funded by Armenian advocacy organizations which includes various recommendations for how to calculate a possible reparations package. Genocide scholar [[Henry C. Theriault]] who chaired the panel has said that the question of reparations is "obviously a pretty central one". The Turkish government position is that reparations do not need to paid for the events of 1915. Human rights historians have said that recognition by Turkey would undermine any legal defense Turkey might have to future compensation claims.{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Gladstone| first = Rick| title = Armenian Groups Are Increasingly Focused on Reparations for Genocide| work = The New York Times| accessdate = 2018-02-07| date = 2015-04-23| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/24/world/europe/turkey-fear-of-reparations-possibly-in-many-billions-is-a-factor-in-armenian-genocide-denials.html}} [[Taner Akçam|Taner Akcam]] has written the following:{{Cite book| publisher = Zed Books| isbn = 978-1-84277-527-1| last = Akçam| first = Taner| title = From Empire to Republic: Turkish Nationalism and the Armenian Genocide| date = 2004-09-04}}
In Turkish discourse, the following argument is commonly heard: "If we accept the Genocide, then the claim for reparations will soon follow." It shows that the main fear is not what we should call the event, but what comes after the event.
According to Fatma Muge Gocek, many Turkish journalists have viewed the issue of recognition as "an imposition on the Turkish state and society, one that would solely benefit the Armenians". In one editoral a Turkish journalist wrote "If you once acknowledge, then see what will happen next? From demands for restitution to land...".{{Cite book| publisher = Oxford University Press| isbn = 978-0-19-062458-3| last = Gocek| first = Fatma Muge| title = Denial of Violence: Ottoman Past, Turkish Present, and Collective Violence Against the Armenians, 1789-2009| date = 2016-04-07}} ==Efforts at rebuttal== The Ottoman Empire wanted to remove the threat of [[Armenian resistance]] and the Turkish authorities today hold the position that the deaths incurred by Armenians as a whole were the result of the turmoil of [[World War I]] and that the [[Ottoman Empire]] was fighting against Russia, [[Armenian volunteer units]], and the [[Armenian militia]]. However, the Armenians had neither a police force nor an army.Grenke, Arthur. ''God, greed, and genocide: the Holocaust through the centuries''. 2005, page 58. Heather Rae noted that scholars have long been denied access to Ottoman archives, which Turkish sources often refer to in their works. In the late 1980s access was granted to some archives by the Turkish government, but it appears that the material was limited and the government took a very selective approach to who was allowed to study the material.Heather Rae. ''State Identities and the Homogenisation of Peoples''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002, p. 128. {{ISBN|0-521-79708-X}}.[[Vahakn Dadrian]]. "Ottoman archives and Denial of the Armenian Genocide" in ''The Armenian Genocide: History, Politics and Ethics''. [[Richard G. Hovannisian]] (ed.) New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 1992. Historian [[Taner Akcam]] also writes about the "careful selection" of Ottoman archive materials. "While we are missing a significant portion of these papers, what remains in the Ottoman archives and in court records is sufficient to show that the [[Committee of Union and Progress|CUP]] Central Committee, and the [[Special Organization (Ottoman Empire)|Special Organization]] is set up to carry out its plan, did deliberately attempt to destroy the Armenian population".Akcam. ''A Shameful Act'', p. 5. ===Inter-ethnic violence=== According to McCarthy, the genocide was a two sided battle: "when they [the Armenians] advanced victoriously under the protection of the [[Imperial Russian Army|Russian Army]], the same spectacle occurred as in 1915, but this time it was Turks who were attacked by Armenians, aided and possibly commanded and directed by Russia."McCarthy, Justin. ''Death and Exile: The Ethnic Cleansing of Ottomon Muslims, 1821–1922''. ===Deportations=== The Turkish authorities maintain the position that the Ottoman Empire did not exercise the degree of control which the opposing parties claim. Turkey accepts that there were Armenian deaths as a result of Ottoman decisions, but states that the responsible Ottoman bureaucrats and military personnel were tried. [[Bernard Lewis]] believes that what he names the "tremendous massacres"Lewis, Bernard. "[http://www.armenian--genocide.com/2007/10/professor-bernard-lewis-condemns.html Distinguishing the Armenian Case from the Holocaust]", April 14, 2002. [[National Press Club (USA)|National Press Club]] on [[C-SPAN2]]'s [[Book TV]]. were not "a deliberate preconceived decision of the Ottoman government".Getler, Michael. "[https://www.pbs.org/ombudsman/2006/04/documenting_and_debating_a_genocide.html Documenting and Debating a 'Genocide']", ''Ombudsman Column'', [[PBS]], 21 April 2006. Retrieved 9 October 2006. ===Casualties=== [[File:Armenian Genocide Museum Yerevan courtesy of american times 10.jpg|thumb|Survivors]] Turkish scholars and other denialists reject the academic consensus of up to 1.5 million Armenian deaths attributed to the genocide. McCarthy calculated an estimate of the pre-war Armenian population, then subtracted his estimate of survivors, arriving at a figure of less than 600,000 for Armenian casualties for the period 1914 to 1922.Justin McCarthy, ''The End of Ottoman Anatolia'', in ''Muslims and Minorities: The Population of Ottoman Anatolia and the End of the Empire'', New York Univ. Press, 1983. However, in a more recent essay, he projected that if the Armenian records of 1913 were accurate, 250,000 more deaths should be added, for a total of 850,000.Justin McCarthy, ''The Population of the Ottoman Armenians'', in ''The Armenians in the Late Ottoman Period'', The Turkish Historical Society For The Council Of Culture, Arts And Publications Of The Grand National Assembly Of Turkey, Ankara, 2001, pp. 65–86 McCarthy's numbers were highly criticized by academia for underrepresenting the actual numbers. Some of them, like Frédéric Paulin, have severely criticized McCarthy's [[methodology]] and suggested that it is flawed.Frédéric Paulin, ''Négationnisme et théorie des populations stables : le cas du génocide arménien'', in Hervé Lebras (dir.), ''L'Invention des populations. Biologie, Idéologie et politique'', Editions Odile Jacob, 2000. Hilmar KaiserHilmar Kaiser, a German expert on the Armenian genocide, also criticizes McCarthy's calculation techniques in an interview with Dirk van Delft published in the ''NRC Handelsblad'', p. 51, Amsterdam, Saturday, 27 May 2000 another specialist has made similar claims, as have professor [[Vahakn N. Dadrian]]Vahakn N. Dadrian, ''Warrant for Genocide: Key Elements of Turko-Armenian Conflict'', New Brunswick, N.J.: Transaction Publishers, 1999. See also his essay: ''Ottoman Archives and Denial of the Armenian Genocide'', in ''The Armenian Genocide: History, Politics, Ethics'', R.G. Hovanissian, ed. New York: St. Martin's Press, 1992 pp. 294–97 and professor Levon Marashlian.Levon Marashlian, ''Politics and Demography: Armenians, Turks and Kurds in the Ottoman Empire'', Zoryan Inst for Contemporary Armenian Research & Documentation Inc. September, 1990 The critics not only question McCarthy's methodology and resulting calculations, but also his primary sources, the Ottoman censuses. They point out that there was no official statistic census in 1912; rather those numbers were based on the records of 1905 which were conducted during the reign of Sultan Hamid.Kemal H. Karpat, ''Ottoman Population 1830–1914: Demographic and Social Characteristics'', Madiscon, WI: University of Wisconsin Press, 1985. See also ''Tableau indicant le nombre des divers éléments de la population dans l'Empire Ottoman au 1er Mars 1330 (14 Mars 1914)'', Istanbul: Zellitch Brothers, 1919. Foreword by Refet. FO 371/4229/86552. May 1919. While Ottoman censuses claimed an Armenian population of 1.2 million, [[Fa'iz El-Ghusein]] (the [[Kaimakam]] of [[Kharpout]]) wrote that there were about 1.9 million Armenians in the Ottoman Empire,{{Cite book | title = Martyred Armenia | last = El-Ghusein | first = Fa'iz | author-link = Faiz El-Ghusein | year = 1917 | page = [[s:Page:Martyred Armenia – El-Ghusein.djvu/9|7]] }} and some modern scholars estimate over 2 million. German official [[Max Erwin von Scheubner-Richter]] wrote that fewer than 100,000 Armenians survived the genocide, the rest having been exterminated ({{lang-de |ausgerottet}}).Fisk, Robert (2005), The Great War for Civilisation: The Conquest of the Middle East, New York: Alfred A Knopf, {{ISBN|1-84115-007-X}}. {{rp |329–30}} ==Conflict resolution== {{See also|Armenian-Turkish relations}} The Turkish authorities have put forth certain conditions before attempting to reconcile with Armenia. Turkey closed its border with Armenia in 1993 following the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]] between Armenia and [[Turkic languages|Turkic-speaking]] [[Azerbaijan]]. The borders have remained closed because the Nagorno-Karabakh dispute has not been settled to this day.{{Cite news | title = Fears of Turkey's 'invisible' Armenians | last = Rainsford | first = Sarah | publisher = [[BBC News]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/5102564.stm | date = 22 June 2006 }} In 2005 Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] invited Turkish, Armenian and international historians to form a commission to reevaluate the events of 1915 by using archives in Turkey, Armenia and other countries.{{Cite web |title=Turkey's Initiative to Resolve Armenian Allegations Regarding 1915 |publisher=Embassy of Turkish Republic at Washington, D.C. |url=http://www.turkishembassy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=612&Itemid=338 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070730160258/http://www.turkishembassy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=612&Itemid=338 |access-date=23 April 2007 |archive-date=30 July 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Armenian president [[Robert Kocharian]] responded,
Your proposal to address the past can't be effective if it does not refer to the present and the future. To start an effective dialog, we should create a favorable political environment. The governments are responsible for the development of bilateral relations, and we have no right to delegate that responsibility to the historians. Thus, we have proposed and we again propose to establish normal relations between our countries without preconditions. In this regard, an inter-governmental commission can be formed to discuss the outstanding issues to resolve them and maintain mutual understanding.{{Cite web |title=Minister Oskanian Comments on Turkish Foreign Minister Abdullah Gul's Recent Remarks |publisher=Armenian Ministry of Foreign Affairs |url=http://www.armeniaforeignministry.com/pr_06/061104_vo_gul.html |date=4 November 2006 |access-date=23 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213220855/http://www.armeniaforeignministry.com/pr_06/061104_vo_gul.html |archivedate=13 February 2012 |df=dmy }}{{Cite web | title = WikiLeaks Publishes Robert Kocharyan's Letter to Prime Minister Erdogan | publisher = YerevanReport | url = http://www.yerevanreport.com/83181/wikileaks-publishes-robert-kocharyans-letter-prime-minister-erdogan/ | date = 25 August 2011 }}
===Documentation and historical study=== The Concerned Scholars and Writers says the Turkish government attempts "to sanitize its history now include the funding of chairs in Turkish studies – with strings attached – at American universities".Statement on Armenian Genocide by Concerned Scholars and Writers, 1998, cited by [[Yair Auron]], The Banality of Denial, Transaction Publishers, 2004, {{ISBN|0-7658-0834-X}}, p. 303 ====Talat Pasha telegrams==== {{See also|The Memoirs of Naim Bey|Aram Andonian}} Many references that cite genocidal intent use the "Talat Pasha telegrams", which are a series of documents by the Interior Minister [[Mehmed Talat Pasha]], to constitute concrete evidence that the deaths were implemented as a state policy. Pasha was tied to the "Kill every Armenian man, woman, and child without concern" order in these documents.[https://books.google.com/books?id=feq-KS57zeUC&dq= Congressional Record, V. 151, Pt. 6, 21 April 2005 to 5 May 2005, Part 16] (2009), p. 758: Rep. [[Anthony Weiner]] Commemorates Armenian Genocide ==Denialism by prominent figures== ===The 69 American historians – the "Lewis Affair"=== On 19 May 1985, ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]'' ran an advertisement in which a group of 69 American historians called on Congress not to adopt the resolution on the Armenian Genocide.''[[Yves Ternon]]''. The "Lewis Affair" // ''[[Richard G. Hovannisian]]''. Remembrance and denial: the case of the Armenian genocide. Wayne State University Press, 1998. {{ISBN|0-8143-2777-X}}, 9780814327777. pp. 237–348. "''The "Lewis Affair" began in the United States on May 19, 1985, with the publication, both in the New York Times and in the Washington Post, of an advertisement addressed to members of the House of Representatives. The statement was signed by sixty-nine academics in Turkish studies and sponsored by the Assembly of Turkish American Associations. Among the signatories was the name of Bernard Lewis, the Cleveland E. Dodge Professor of Near Eastern History at Princeton University.''" [[Bernard Lewis]], along with [[Heath Lowry]], was among them and so the case was named after him.''W. D. Rubinstein''. Genocide: a history, Pearson Education, 2004. {{ISBN|0-582-50601-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-582-50601-5}}. p. 145 "''This was an element in the so-called 'Lewis Affair', which occurred in 1985 when Professor Bernard Lewis of Princeton University, one of the world's leading experts on modern Turkish history, signed a statement addressed to the American Congress concerning the inclusion of the Armenian genocide in a proposed `National Day of Remembrance of Man's Inhumanity to Man`''"''Yair Auron''. The banality of denial: Israel and the Armenian genocide. Transaction Publishers, 2004. {{ISBN|0-7658-0834-X}}, 9780765808349. pp. 226–27 ""The Bernard Lewis Affair:" 1997" "''The rationalization of the Armenian Genocide began to take root in Western academic circles in the 1980s, and was further strengthened by the hiring of Bernard Lewis at Princeton University. Lewis is one of the most prominent specialists on the Middle East — some would say the most distinguished historian of the Middle East. Lewis' stature provided a lofty cover for the Turkish national agenda of obfuscating academic research on the Armenian Genocide. <...> Later on Bernard Lewis reversed his position and changed the text. In 1985 he signed a petition to the U.S. Congress protesting the plan to make April 24, the day on which the Armenians commemorate the victims of the Genocide, a national American-Armenian memorial day, mentioning man's inhumanity to man. Lewis' signature was the most significant of sixty-nine signatures published. A two-page spread appeared simultaneously in the New York Times and Washington Post, financed by the Committee of the Turkish Associations.''" The advertisement was paid for by the Committee of the Turkish Associations.''Richard G. Hovannisian''. [https://books.google.com/books?id=kiBHkRtRmIIC&pg=PA224 Remembrance and denial: the case of the Armenian genocide.] Wayne State University Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-8143-2777-X}}, 9780814327777. p. 224 "''The Institute of Turkish Studies and its director. Heath Lowry, were instrumental in securing the signature of sixty-nine academics in Turkish studies, many of whom had been awarded grants by the institute, for an open letter published as an advertisement in the New York Times and the Washington Post, and read more than once into the Congressional Record.''" Both Lewis and Lowry have been included among the ''key deniers'' of the Armenian Genocide.[http://www.ideajournal.com/articles.php?id=27 The Psychological Satisfaction of Denials of the Holocaust or Other Genocides by Non-Extremists or Bigots, and Even by Known Scholars], by Israel Charny, "IDEA" journal, 17 July 2001, Vol. 6, no. 1Identity Politics in the Age of Genocide: The Holocaust and Historical Representation, By David B. Smith, [[Eric Markusen]] and [[Robert Jay Lifton]], Lowry was also advising on how to prevent mention of the Armenian Genocide in scholarly works, and was discovered [[ghost writing]] for the Turkish ambassador in Washington on issues regarding the Embassy's denial of the Armenian Genocide.Smith, Roger W.; Markusen, Eric; Lifton, Robert Jay (Spring 1995). "Professional Ethics and the Denial of Armenian Genocide". Holocaust and Genocide Studies 9 (1): 1–22. The [[Armenian Assembly of America]] found that many or most of the 69 academics apparently benefited directly or indirectly from Turkish government research grants.[[Kenneth S. Stern]]. ''Holocaust Denial''. Amer Jewish Committee, 1993. {{ISBN|0-87495-102-X}}. pp. 86–87.[http://www.ideajournal.com/articles.php?id=27 The Psychological Satisfaction of Denials of the Holocaust or Other Genocides by Non-Extremists or Bigots, and Even by Known Scholars], by Israel Charny, "IDEA" journal, 17 July 2001, Vol. 6, no. 1 "''In the immediate shock of the appearance of the new virulent form of double talk back in 1985, the Armenian Assembly of America rapidly undertook investigation of the academic records and especially the history of research grants received by the 69 signators (Armenian Assembly of America, 1987). The Assembly revealed first of all that a majority of the scholars were not specialists in the subject matter of the period of the genocide, and more importantly that a very large number of the signators were recipients of grants from Turkish government sources. [[Speros Vryonis]] (1993) has since reviewed the data and has similarly concluded that a considerable number of the signators, and their institutions, were direct recipients of research funds from Turkey.''" According to [[Yair Auron]], an Israeli historian, scholar and expert specializing in genocide studies and racism, this advertisement is a good example of one of many Turkish attempts to influence academia, a project on which Turkey has spent enormous funds.''Yair Auron''. The banality of denial: Israel and the Armenian Genocide. Jacobs''. Pioneers of genocide studies. Transaction Publishers, 2002. {{ISBN|0-7658-0151-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7658-0151-7}}. pp. 456–64. However, [[Henry Morgenthau Sr.]] wrote that "When the Turkish authorities gave the orders for these deportations, they were merely giving the death warrant to a whole race; they understood this well, and, in their conversations with me, they made no particular attempt to conceal the fact."Morgenthau, Henry (1918), [https://books.google.com/books?id=ENsLAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=morgenthau%27s+story#PRA1-PA336,M1 Ambassador Morgenthau's Story], Garden City, New York: Doubleday, p. 309. Milliyet. 02.10.2000 ====The resignation of Donald Quataert==== One of the 69 signatories of the 1985 statement to the US Congress was Donald Quataert. He resigned from the position of the chairman of the board of directors of the Institute of Turkish Studies, which he had held since 2001. As he announced, he had to resign due to the pressure of the Turkish ambassador Nabi Shensoy after he characterised the massacres of Armenians in Turkey as genocide. Shensoy rejected the allegations. Quataert's resignation created a scandal in academia and a number of members of the board of directors of the Institute resigned as well after the announcement. [[Mervat Hatem]] the director of [[Middle East Studies Association]] addressed the Prime Minister of Turkey Erdogan a harsh letter, whereby he expressed grave concerns with the announcements of Turkish officials to stop the financing of the Institute if Quataert didn't renounce his assessments publicly. Hatem also noted, that "the resignations are in contradiction with those many requests to leave the discussion and the assessment of the Armenian Genocide to the academia (instead of discussing it on the political arena) that Turkey has been making." According to the announcement by Quataert, the members of the board of directors on the Institute of Turkish Studies were surprised to find out, that the funding of the institute by Turkey is not a sign of trust but a gift, that can be annulled at any moment.''David Holthouse''. [http://www.splcenter.org/blog/2008/06/06/institute-of-turkish-studies-chair-forced-out-for-rebuking-genocide-deniers/ Institute of Turkish Studies Chair Forced Out For Rebuking Genocide Deniers]. Southern Poverty Law Center, 6 June 2008''Susan Kinzie''. Board Members Resign to Protest Chair's Ousting. The Washington Post. 5 July 2008[http://reporting.sunlightfoundation.com/2009/defense-contractors-join-turkish-lobbying-effort-in-pursuit-of- Defense contractors join Turkish lobbying effort in pursuit of arms deals, 17 December 2009, Sunlight Foundation.] ===Comparison with Holocaust and Israeli stance=== Officially the state of [[Israel]] neither recognizes nor denies the Armenian Genocide. Politicians from primarily left wing and centrist parties such as [[Meretz]] and [[Kadima]], but also occasionally right wing parties such as [[Likud]], have been promoting recognition and commemoration of the Armenian Genocide. This cooperation is significant since it includes activists and politicians who usually are on the opposing sides of the political spectrum.[http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/MK-fails-to-block-Knesset-talks-on-Armenian-genocide] Yet the official line of all Israeli governments has been to keep the status quo, partially because of modern-day real-politik reasons. Right-wing party [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] (Israel Our Home) claims that Genocide discussions would jeopardise [[Azerbaijan–Israel relations|Israel-Azerbaijan]] and [[Israel–Turkey relations|Israel-Turkish relations]] and hurt close economic and military cooperation with them. These two countries are essential for Israel's regional policy and interests opposing [[Iran]]. In 2008, [[Yosef Shagal]], an Azerbaijani Jew and now retired Israeli parliamentarian from Israel Our Home stated in an interview to Azerbaijan media (which officially denies the genocide): "I find it deeply offensive, and even blasphemous to compare the Holocaust of European Jewry during the Second World War with the mass extermination of the Armenian people during the First World War. Jews were killed because they were Jews, but Armenians provoked Turkey and should blame themselves."{{Cite web | title = Депутат парламента Израиля: "Считаю глубоко оскорбительными и даже богохульственными попытки сравнивать Катастрофу европейского еврейства в годы Второй мировой войны с массовым истреблением армянского народа в годы Первой мировой войны" | work = DAY.AZ | url = http://news.day.az/armenia/112536.html | date = 28 March 2008 }} Despite this controversy, there are several prominent Armenian Genocide Memorials in the State of Israel.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} To commemorate the 100th anniversary of the genocide, the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra performed music written by Armenian composers.{{Cite web | title = Concert in Jerusalem to Commemorate Genocide Centennial | author = Contributor | publisher = Asbarez.com | url = http://asbarez.com/132163/concert-in-jerusalem-to-commemorate-genocide-centennial/ | date = 25 February 2015 | access-date = 9 January 2016 }} Many Israeli and Jewish historians also draw parallels between the genocides. [[Hebrew University]] scholar [[Yehuda Bauer]] wrote:{{Cite book | title = Holocaust: Religious & Philosophical Implications | last1 = Bauer | first1 = Yehuda | editor1-last = Roth | editor1-first = John K. | editor2-last = Berenbaum | editor2-first = Michael | chapter = The Place of the Holocaust in Contemporary History | publisher = Paragon House | date = 1998 | isbn = 978-1-55778-212-0 }} {{quote|The differences between the holocaust and the Armenian massacres are less important than the similarities—and even if the Armenian case is not seen as a holocaust in the extreme form which it took towards Jews, it is certainly the nearest thing to it.}} Israel's president Rivlin once campaigned for Israel to recognize the [[Armenian Genocide]].{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/knesset-speaker-working-to-boost-recognition-of-armenian-genocide-1.365034 |title=Knesset Speaker working to boost recognition of Armenian genocide |publisher=Haaretz.com |accessdate=2015-03-27}} In 2012, he said "It is our moral duty to remember and remind of the tragedy that befell the Armenian people, who lost more than a million of its sons during the First World War, and we must not make this a political issue. I am aware of the sensitivity of this issue. But let us be clear: This is not an accusation of Turkey today or of the current Turkish government."{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/156818#.U5dcEvRDuSo |title=Rivlin: We Cannot Ignore the Armenian Genocide - Inside Israel - News - Arutz Sheva |publisher=Israelnationalnews.com |date=2012-06-13 |accessdate=2015-03-27}} As president he has been less vocal on this issue. University of Utah Press, 2005. {{ISBN|0-87480-849-9}}. ==External links== * [http://www.teachgenocide.com/bkgrnd/denial.htm Denial of the Armenian Genocide, Armenian Genocide Resource Library for Teachers] * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618100356/http://www.genocidewatch.org/news/TURKEY.htm |date=18 June 2007 |title=Armenian genocide denial by Turkey }}, Genocide Watch * [http://www.noplacefordenial.com/ A source of news and information on the No Place for Hate/Anti-Defamation League Armenian Genocide denial issue] * [http://www.facinghistory.org/resources/lessons/armenian-genocide-lesson-eight-d Armenian Genocide Denial and Free Speech, by ''FacingHistory.ORG'', 2008] * [http://www.zoryaninstitute.org/Table_Of_Contents/genocide_biblio_denial.htm Selected Bibliography on Denial of the Armenian Genocide], [[Zoryan Institute]], 2001. * [http://www.deutscharmenischegesellschaft.de/?page_id=2819 The Armenian Genocide at the German Bundestag (Parliament)] * [http://www.genocide-museum.am/eng/index.php The Armenian Genocide Museum-Institute] * [http://www.english.rfi.fr/europe/20120125-frances-armenian-genocide-bill-who-what-where-why France's Armenian genocide bill] Radio France International in English * [http://armenocide.am/Turkey_genocide_denial.html Armenian Genocide Denial] * [http://armeniangenocide100.org/en/ Official Website of Armenian Genocide Centennial] {{Armenian Genocide}} {{Foreign relations of Armenia}} {{Historical revisionism}} {{Conspiracy theories}} {{Genocide topics}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Anti-Armenianism]] [[Category:Genocide denial]] [[Category:Historical revisionism (negationism)]] [[Category:Pseudohistory]] [[Category:Armenian Genocide denial]]

[[File:Crosby Garrett Helmet on auction at Christies.jpg|300px|thumb|An art auction, as in this one at Christies, is an example of one part of the art market where buyers and sellers of art meet to conduct transactions in the art market]] :{{see also|Art valuation|Art auction}} The art market is represented by a marketplace of buyers and sellers trading in the commodities, services, and works-of-art commonly associated with the various arts. The art market is also concerned with the production of new art which enters the art market. The art market is an example of one type of marketplace, among many different types of markets which occur in economics. In particular, the art market has many similarities with other marketplaces where buyers and sellers meet, as well as significant distinguishing factors indicative of its differences from other types of markets in economics.
==The art market economic model== The [[Economics of the arts and literature#The market for artworks|art market]] operates in an economic model that considers more than [[supply and demand]]: it is a hybrid type of [[prediction market]] where art is bought and sold for values based not only on a work's perceived cultural value, but on both its past monetary value as well as its predicted future value. The market has been described as one where producers don't make work primarily for sale, where buyers often have no idea of the value of what they buy, and where middlemen routinely claim reimbursement for sales of things they have never seen to buyers they have never dealt with.<ref name="platter">Plattner, Stuart, [http://www.stuartplattner.com/AA-ART-Paradox.pdf A Most Ingenious Paradox: The Market for Contemporary Fine Art], ''[[American Anthropologist]]'' 100(2):482-493, 1998.</ref> Moreover, the market is not transparent; private sales data is not systematically available<ref name="Coslor">{{Cite journal|last=Coslor|first=Erica|date=April 2016|title=Transparency in an opaque market: Evaluative frictions between "thick" valuation and "thin" price data in the art market|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0361368216300307|journal=Accounting, Organizations and Society|volume=50|pages=13–26|doi=10.1016/j.aos.2016.03.001}}</ref> and private sales represent about half of market transactions.
===Market size=== Unlike the volumes in the [[securities market]] where millions of people and firms participate in buying and selling financial interests, or the [[Commodity market|commodities market]] where measures of raw or primary products are exchanged using standardized contracts, art market activity largely follows the demands of a more limited array of private collectors, museums, and large corporate interests as the principal market participants.<ref name="microcosm">The art market sees itself as a microcosm: it lists its collectors in the hundreds, as opposed to the securities market which has millions of participants. ''ARTnews'': [http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2536 The Top Ten] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016003020/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2536 |date=16 October 2009 }}, [http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2520 The ARTnews 200 Top Collectors] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016003056/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2520 |date=16 October 2009 }}. One art writer, however, answered the question: "Do you see the art world as a microcosm of other broader, power communities?" with the following observation: "I'm not sure if it's a microcosm or the shape of things to come. Its manic internationalism...." [http://www.vmagazine.com/2008/11/111208-insider-art/ Insider Art]{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''V Magazine'', 2008-11-12, vmagazine.com. Accessed 20 June 2012.</ref> Corporate collectors, however, can have a disparately large market impact, for instance, ''[[Spear's Wealth Management Survey|Spear's]]'' reported in 2015 that [[British Rail]] began investing in art for its pension fund beginning in 1974 (prior to privatization), spending about £40M or approximately 3% of its funds on art, before selling those assets between 1987–1999.<ref name="britrailspears">Lindsay, Ivan, [http://www.spearswms.com/news/go-figure/#.U4W0eSj8iZQ Go Figure], ''Spear's'', spearswms.com, 21 January 2011; free [https://web.archive.org/web/20140529052940/http://www.spearswms.com/news/go-figure/ archived version]. Accessed 17 November 2015. The article also mentions that British Rail Pension realized an annualized return of 11.3% because of a number of factors particular to the market at the time.</ref> British Rail's efforts realized profits, particularly due to the Impressionist portfolio, but the collection was liquidated because it came to be seen as an illegitimate investment area, particularly as alternative investments became available.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coslor|first=Erica|last2=Spaenjers|first2=Christophe|date=November 2016|title=Organizational and epistemic change: The growth of the art investment field|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0361368216300782|journal=Accounting, Organizations and Society|volume=55|pages=48–62|doi=10.1016/j.aos.2016.09.003}}</ref> Also, because original artworks are not [[Fungibility|fungible]] like [[stock]]s, they have valuation challenges not similarly affecting securities,<ref name="baumol">Baumol, William J., [http://pchen.ccer.edu.cn/homepage/RecommendPapers/BaumolArts86.pdf Unnatural Value: Or Art Investment as Floating Crap Game] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425235014/http://pchen.ccer.edu.cn/homepage/RecommendPapers/BaumolArts86.pdf |date=25 April 2012 }}, ''The American Economic Review'', 76:2 (May 1986), pp. 10-14, Papers and Proceedings of the Ninety-Eighth Annual Meeting of the American Economic Association,; ''Journal of Arts Management and Law'' (now ''The Journal of Arts Management, Law, and Society''), 15:3, 1985, pp. 47-60. {{DOI|10.1080/07335113.1985.9942162}}.</ref> with dynamics of what Karpik calls singularities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/9215.html|title=Valuing the Unique|website=Princeton University Press|access-date=9 June 2017}}</ref>
Thus, because the art market's participants are far more limited in number than the securities or commodities markets, because artworks are not fungible, and because art valuation relies to a great extent on the advice and enthusiasm of a variety of specialized market analysts, these limitations each in turn dictate the size of the market and increase the risk that some items may be over or undervalued.
===Market timing=== The art market moves in cycles with activity generally peaking in the spring and autumn when the major auction houses traditionally schedule auctions, and results in the market being seasonal rather than ongoing.<ref name="sched">[http://www.artmarket.com/ Art Market Cycles], artmarket.com, retrieved 20 November 2011.</ref> While private sales take place all year, those sales are often not publicized as auctions are and thus do not affect the market until they become known.
Art valuations made for an autumn auction may be unrealistic for the following spring auction season because fortunes in the financial markets during one season can affect the art market in the following season, and equity markets do significantly impact the art market.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Goetzmann|first=William N|last2=Renneboog|first2=Luc|last3=Spaenjers|first3=Christophe|date=May 2011|title=Art and Money|url=http://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/aer.101.3.222|journal=American Economic Review|language=en|volume=101|issue=3|pages=222–226|doi=10.1257/aer.101.3.222|issn=0002-8282}}</ref> Volatility in the financial markets often causes volatility in the art market as happened in the contraction of the art market during the [[2008–2012 global recession|2008-2009 recession]]<ref>For more on the economic background causing the market contraction, see also the [[2008–2009 Keynesian resurgence]].</ref> when sales at [[Sotheby's]], [[Christie's]], and [[Phillips de Pury & Company]] were less than half the previous year: November 2008, $803.3 million compared to November 2007, $1.75 billion; and between 2000 and 2003 when the annual volume of art works sold at auction dropped 36%.<ref name="sched" /><ref name="contraction">Esterow, [http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2642 How to Buy in 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015210756/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2642 |date=15 October 2009 }}, ''ARTnews'', March 2009.</ref> In other instances, the art market can fare reasonably well despite volatility in the stock market such as happened from January 1997 through May 2004 when the average quarterly fluctuation in the Artprice Global Index was two to three times smaller than the same statistic for the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] and the [[S&P 500]].<ref name="sched" />
As art market participants' fortunes wax and wane in the financial markets, buying power evolves and affects participants' ability to afford highly valued works, resulting in new buyers and sellers entering, leaving, or re-entering the market, and an artwork sold to offset losses in the financial market might be sold for substantially more or substantially less than its last {{H:title|price for which work sold at auctioneer's hammer strike|hammer value|link=no}} at auction.<ref name="gerber">Gerber, Manuel, [http://www.gerberstauffer.com/GerberAFT1108.pdf Primary Art Market Investments - A Safe Haven when All Else Suddenly Correlates?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002174957/http://www.gerberstauffer.com/GerberAFT1108.pdf# |date=2013-10-02 }}, Prime Art Management Ltd., published in ''Art Fund Tracker'', Nov. 2008.</ref> In the late 1980s during the stock-market boom, the art market expanded in turn with prices soaring to new heights, and investment firms took a greater interest in the art market and began to study it in-depth.<ref name="campbell">Campbell, [http://i1.exhibit-e.com/collectionofmodernart/39049d22.pdf The Art of Portfolio Diversification]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Maastricht University, March 2004. (art as an asset class)</ref><ref name="goetzmann">Goetzmann, William N., Accounting for Taste: Art and the Financial Markets Over Three Centuries, ''The American Economic Review'', 83(5), Dec. 1993, pp. 1370-1376.</ref> Concurrently, the previously non-transparent art market became more accessible via the increasing availability of indices and online data<ref name="campbellRAJ">Campbell, R.A.J., [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/Delivery.cfm/SSRN_ID978467_code230208.pdf?abstractid=978467&rulid=6936564&mirid=1 Art as a Financial Investment], Erasmus Univ., Rotterdam, Maastricht Univ., 2007.</ref> although researchers discovered biased price estimates in the auction houses.<ref name="mei">Mei, J. and Moses, M., [http://pages.stern.nyu.edu/~jmei/estimates.pdf Vested Interest and Biased Price Estimates: Evidence from an Auction Market], ''The Journal of Finance'', 60(5), 2005, pp. 2409-2435.</ref>
Art sometimes has transient fashionability that also can affect its value: what sells well for a time may be supplanted in the market by new styles and ideas in short order. For instance, in the spring of 2008 a collector offered over $80 million for Jeff Koons' stainless-steel ''Rabbit'', and yet a year later, of four works in the fall auctions at Christie's and Sotheby's in New York, only two of his pieces sold well and one failed to sell entirely.<ref name="inflatable">[http://www.economist.com/node/14941205 Inflatable investments, The volatile art of Jeff Koons], ''[[The Economist]]'', 28 November 2009.</ref> In 2011, Christie's sold Koons' ''Balloon Flower'' sculpture for $16.9 million.<ref name="koonsballoon">Christie's, [http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/jeff-koons-balloon-flower/5371708/lot/lot_details.aspx?from=searchresults&intObjectID=5371708&sid=e5ce29ac-d2b6-41b6-9092-7aacf3e6974b Auction result, Sale 2355 / Lot 23], christies.com, retrieved 21 November 2011.</ref>
===Primary and secondary markets=== The art market as a whole is affected by its two main parts: the primary art market, where new art comes to the market for the first time, and the secondary market, for existing art that has been sold at least once before. Once a work is sold on the primary market it enters the secondary market, and the prices for which it sold in the primary market have a direct bearing on the work's value in the secondary market. Supply and demand affect the secondary market more than the primary market because works new to the market, mainly contemporary art, have no market history for predictive analysis and thus valuation of such work is more difficult, and more speculative.<ref name="gerald">Gerard and Louis, [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B6V64-3YRSMF4-28/2/44fafa98be1c97504c5a1fdc722b55ba On pricing the priceless: Comments on the economics of the visual art market], ''European Economic Review'', Elsevier, vol. 39(3-4), April 1995, pp. 509-518. (membership required).</ref> Gallery, dealer, consultant, and agent promotion as well as collectors acting as [[alpha consumer]]s (trend-setters) are the forces at work in valuing primary market works.
===Market entry barriers=== As with [[Blue chip (stock market)|blue-chip]] stocks, works by "blue-chip" or well-known artists are generally valued more highly than works by unknown artists since it is hard to predict how an unknown artist's work will sell, or whether it will sell at all. [[barriers to entry|High barriers to market entry]] for artists<ref name="jeffri">Jeffri, Joan, Philanthropy and the American artist: A historical overview, ''[[International Journal of Cultural Policy|The European Journal of Cultural Policy]]'', 3(2), 2009, pp. 207-233.</ref><ref name="barriers">Jackson, M.R., et al, [http://www.urban.org/UploadedPDF/411311_investing_in_creativity.pdf Investing in Creativity: A study of the support structure for US artists], ''The Journal of Arts Management, Law, and Society'', 2004. PDF from Urban Institute, urban.org.</ref> create scarcity in the supply and demand portion of the market, in turn driving up prices and raising questions of [[Financial market efficiency|efficiency]].<ref name="bonus">Bonus, H., Ronte, D., Credibility and economic value in the visual arts, ''Journal of Cultural Economics'' 21, 1997 103–118.</ref><ref name="adler">Adler, M., [http://www.columbia.edu/~ma820/Stardom%20and%20Talent.pdf ''Stardom and Talent''], in Handbook of the Economics of Art and Culture, Vol. 1, Chap. 25, 2006, pp. 895-906.</ref> While a high market entry barrier may result in having a smaller pool of artwork producers in the auction-level portion of the market, and in greater market predictability by virtue of that smaller pool and thus more reliable valuation measures, its axiomatic effect is of lesser artistic diversity negatively impacting the size of the buyer pool.<ref name="schonfeld">Schönfeld and Reinstaller, [http://www.wu-wien.ac.at/inst/vw1/papers/wu-wp90.pdf ''The effects of gallery and artist reputation on prices in the primary market for art'']{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Working Paper, Department of Economics, Vienna University of Economics & B.A., May 2005.</ref> For this reason, gallerists and art dealers consider what types of works are currently in vogue before deciding to represent a new artist and are highly selective in those choices in order to maintain a level of quality that is saleable. All these concerns are in play when gallerists set prices for emerging artists at a much lower level than for established artists.
===Market transparency=== With the [[2007–2012 global financial crisis]], the art market faced criticism for its lack of transparency, its [[Byzantinism|Byzantine]] valuation methods, and a perceived lack of ethical behavior enabled by structural inadequacies in the market itself. In response, a 2009 debate occurred between valuation-setting members of the art market on the proposition that "the art market is less ethical than the stock market". At the end of the debate the audience determined that those debating in agreement with the proposition won the debate.<ref name="morality">Saltz, Jerry, [http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/features/saltz/saltz3-6-09.asp Morality Play], artnet.com, 2009-03-06, discussing the debate and its outcome. Participants included art dealers Richard Feigen and Michael Hue-Williams, collector Adam Lindemann on the "pro" side, and artist [[Chuck Close]], critic Jerry Saltz, and auctioneer Amy Cappellazzo opposing. The [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xpsTNdYeG6U debate video] is available on [[YouTube]].</ref> Of particular note in the debate was the identification of "chandelier bidding" as a practice perceived as ethically questionable. The debaters described "chandelier bidding" as bids from the chandelier, or bids from an unknown source, meaning both the bidding by the auction houses on behalf of the sellers whose items the houses are auctioning (a [[conflict of interest]]), and bidding by unidentified bidders having no intention of buying but bidding in order to drive prices up, all practiced because the auction houses keep secret from bidders a seller's [[Reservation price|reserve price]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/28/arts/design/as-art-market-rise-so-do-questions-of-oversight.html|title=As Art Market Soars, So Do Questions of Oversight|last=Pogrebin|first=Robin|date=27 January 2013|work=The New York Times|access-date=9 June 2017|last2=Flynn|first2=Kevin|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
In 2011, also in response to criticism on the lack of market transparency and counterarguments that more transparency would ruin the market,<ref name="adaa">Art Dealers Association of America (ADAA), [http://www.artdealers.org/events.forum30.html Art Industry Summit] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111216122400/http://www.artdealers.org/events.forum30.html |date=16 December 2011 }}, Transparency in the market: can we have more of it?, 3 March 2011.</ref> ''[[The Art Newspaper]]'' in association with the Art Dealers Association of America convened an Art Industry Summit panel discussion between major art market decision makers, where panelists discussed whether there was a need for more transparency.<ref name="transpADAA">ADAA and The Art Newspaper, Transparency in the market...can we have more of it?, videos [http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1662 Part 1] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304193922/http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1662# |date=2016-03-04 }}, [http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1661 Part 2] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305172450/http://theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1661# |date=2016-03-05 }}, and [http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1660 Part 3] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304110955/http://www.theartnewspaper.tv/content.php?vid=1660# |date=2016-03-04 }}, Host Anna Somers Cocks, ''The Art Newpapaper'', 11 March 2011.</ref> The panelists argued over whether auction houses have built-in conflicts of interest by representing sellers with secret reserves, while at the same time representing to buyers initial valuations on those works at auction time. The debate also included the issue of first and third-party guaranteed bids, and whether sellers' reserve prices should be disclosed so that participants no longer bid on an object they have no chance of buying. In response to criticisms regarding chandelier bidding and unidentified third-party guaranteed bids, Christie's International chairman Edward Dolman countered that, without a secret reserve, illegal cartels of bidders would know in advance information that could facilitate their manipulation of the market and corruption of final valuation by selling price at auction.<ref name="transpADAA2">ADAA, video 3 at 22:05 min, et seq..</ref>
With the art market's weaknesses (especially lack of transparency and conflicts of interests) becoming better known, serious external conversations about market regulation have begun among major market players; for example, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' noted that in early 2015, participants at the January [[World Economic Forum]] meeting attended a lunch seminar where the speaker warned that the global art market needs to be regulated because of systemic weaknesses which enable inside information trading, tax evasion, and money laundering.<ref name="gapper">Gapper, John, [https://web.archive.org/web/20150125081849/http://blogs.ft.com/the-world/2015/01/art-worlds-shady-dealings-under-scrutiny-at-davos Art world’s shady dealings under scrutiny at Davos], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 22 January 2015. Accessed 17 November 2015.</ref>
In terms of academic research, there is work on the opacity of price formation in finance and economics.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=David|first=Géraldine|last2=Oosterlinck|first2=Kim|last3=Szafarz|first3=Ariane|title=Art market inefficiency|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.econlet.2013.06.033|journal=Economics Letters|volume=121|issue=1|pages=23–25|doi=10.1016/j.econlet.2013.06.033}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
== Auction house market structure == The late 1980s were a boom period for art auction houses. However, in early 1990, the market collapsed. The US overtook the EU as the world's largest art market<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Knelman | first1 = Josh | title = Art Theft: Not Such a Pretty Picture | newspaper = [[Toronto Standard]] | date = 5 December 2011 | url = http://www.torontostandard.com/culture-design/art-theft-not-such-a-pretty-picture | accessdate = 28 April 2012 }}</ref> with a global share of 47 per cent by 2001.<ref>{{Citation | last = Bennett | first = Will | title = Red tape and taxes cost Europe lead in art market | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | location = London | date = 8 March 2002 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/1387151/Red-tape-and-taxes-cost-Europe-lead-in-art-market.html | accessdate = October 1, 2012 }}</ref> Ranking second, the UK's world market share hovers around 25 per cent. In continental Europe, France was the market leader while in Asia, Hong Kong continues its dominance. France’s share of the art market has been progressively eroded since the 1950s, when it was the dominant location and sales at Drouot surpassed those of Sotheby’s and Christie’s combined.<ref>{{cite news|last=Adam |first=Georgina |title=Opinion: One-offs, but reassuring signs to the market—especially to Paris? |newspaper=[[The Art Newspaper]] |date=April 1, 2009 |url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/article.asp?id=17186 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090409071446/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/article.asp?id=17186 |archivedate=April 9, 2009 }}</ref> In 2004, the global fine art market turnover was estimated at almost billion.<ref>[http://press.artprice.com/pdf/Trends2004.pdf Art market trends 2004] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116174818/http://press.artprice.com/pdf/trends2004.pdf# |date=2010-11-16 }}, Artprice, artprice.com, 2005.</ref> Art auction sales reached a record billion in 2007, fueled by speculative bidding for artists such as [[Damien Hirst]], [[Jeff Koons]], and [[Richard Prince]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Reyburn | first = Scott | title = Richter Tops Hot Artists as New Buyers Boost Billion Sales | agency = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = December 28, 2011 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-28/richter-tops-hot-artists-as-2011-sales-surge-to-1-7-billion-on-new-buyers.html}}</ref> The recent rise of the Chinese art market, both in terms of the size of its domestic sales and the international significance of its buyers, has, combined with a rich cultural heritage of art and antiques, produced a huge domestic market and ended the duopoly held by London and New York for over 50 years.<ref>Clare McAndrew (March 14, 2013), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/US-retakes-top-spot-in-art-sales-from-China-/29104 US retakes top spot in art sales from China] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318200710/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/US-retakes-top-spot-in-art-sales-from-China-/29104 |date=2013-03-18 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref>
=== Competitors === Christie's and Sotheby's are the leading auction venues. In 2002, [[LVMH]] acquired Swiss art advisory firm de Pury & Luxembourg and merged it with Phillips to form [[Phillips de Pury & Company]], with the aim of breaking the duopoly at the top of the market.
=== Segments === Fine art auctions are generally held separately for Impressionist and Modern art as well as for Post-war and Contemporary Art. [[Pablo Picasso]]'s works remain the most coveted lot as of 2004. In 2008 just over million of art by [[Damien Hirst]] was sold at auction, a world record for a living artist; however in 2009, Hirst’s annual auction sales had shrunk by 93%.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Hands up for Hirst - How the bad boy of Brit-Art grew rich at the expense of his investors | magazine = [[The Economist]] | date = September 9, 2010 | url = http://www.economist.com/node/16990811}}</ref>
=== Estimates === "Estimates" often reflect the [[consignor]]'s ambitions as much as the auction specialist's considered opinion. They do not reflect commissions. To secure consignments, auction houses concede high estimates to suit the requirements of art owners.<ref>Souren Melikian, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/08/arts/08iht-melikian08.html When Auction Estimates Go Haywire], ''[[The New York Times]]'', nytimes.com, October 7, 2011.</ref> Before an auction, interested buyers typically turn for advice to the auction house specialist who quotes the estimate and often recommends going beyond in order to secure the item.<ref>Souren Melikian, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/arts/18iht-melik19.1.9319140.html Behind stellar sales of art market, a dangerous game], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, January 18, 2008.</ref>
=== Commissions and Buyer's Premium === Auction houses operate contractually on behalf of sellers of goods, charging sellers a fixed [[commission (remuneration)|commission]] (fee) amounting to a percentage of the “hammer price” for which a lot is sold.<ref name="horror">{{cite journal | title = Hammer houses of horror | magazine = [[The Economist]] | date = July 24, 1997 | url = http://www.economist.com/node/152446 | accessdate = 2012-11-20}}</ref> Christie's published its commissions in September 1995, with its fees ranging from 20% on the least expensive lots to 2% on lots sold for over m; Sotheby's followed suit.<ref name="horror" /> For Phillips de Pury & Company, final prices include commission of 25% of the first 20% of the next to million, and 12% of the rest, with estimates not reflecting commissions.<ref>Carol Vogel, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/14/arts/design/14auction.html Phillips Sale Totals Less Than Half the Low Estimate] ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, November 13, 2008.</ref> Objects sold are also subject to a further fee called the "[[buyer's premium]]", 15% being typical, with the term implying that by virtue of selling an object, the auction house performs a service for the buyer subject to remuneration. Thus, both the seller and the buyer of an object or lot sold by the major auction houses pay a fee. First implemented in 1975 by Christie's, the assessment of a buyer's premium is one of several auction-house practices to which art dealers object.<ref>Orley Ashenfelter & Kathryn Graddy, Anatomy of the Rise and Fall of a Pricefixing Conspiracy: Auctions At Sotheby’s And Christie’s, ''Journal of Competition Law and Economics'', 1(1), 3–20, March 2005, {{doi|10.1093/joclec/nhi003}}.</ref>
=== Performance-based fees === Beginning in 2014, Christie's charged 2 percent of the hammer price of a work that meets or exceeds its high estimate. The fee does not apply to online only sales.<ref>Melanie Gerlis (September 26, 2014), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Christies-takes-another-/35708 Christie's takes another 2%] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140928075542/http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Christies-takes-another-/35708 |date=2014-09-28 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref>
=== Guarantees === An auction house may offer a guaranteed selling price, or "guaranteed minimum", a practice designed to give sellers confidence to consign works and to give potential bidders reassurance that there are others willing to buy an item.<ref>[[Sarah Thornton]], [https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2011/11/art-market Financial machinations at auctions], ''The Economist'', economist.com, November 18, 2011.</ref> Auction houses have offered guarantees since the early 1970s to encourage collectors to sell their artworks: ''The Art Newspaper'' reported that guarantees were first introduced in 1971 at Sotheby’s, when 47 [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]]s and other works from the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum|Guggenheim Museum]] were offered with a guaranteed minimum; similar arrangements followed in 1972 and 1973 for the Ritter and Scull collections.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Adam | first1 = Georgina | last2 = Burns | first2 = Charlotte | title = Guaranteed outcome | newspaper = [[The Art Newspaper]] | date = 2 March 2011 | url = http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Guaranteed+outcome/23341 | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last1 = Feinstein | first1 = Roni | title = The Scull Collection | magazine = [[Art in America]] | date = 4 June 2010 | url = http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/reviews/the-scull-collection/ | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref> A guaranteed amount is generally close to the lower estimate, with the seller and the auction house sharing any amount exceeding the guaranteed minimum.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Melikian | first1 = Souren | title = Behind stellar sales of art market, a dangerous game | magazine = [[The New York Times]] | date = 18 January 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/arts/18iht-melik19.1.9319140.html | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref> In autumn 2008 when the market turned sour, Christie's and Sotheby's had to pay out at least million on works for which they guaranteed a minimum price but which failed to sell. In order to reduce their exposure to such losses, boost the market, and reduce volatility, the main auction houses now prefer that third parties take on this financial risk via "third-party guarantees" or "irrevocable bids": using this practice the auction houses sell a work to a third party for a minimum price prior to the auction and this selling price then becomes the “reserve” below which the artwork will not be sold. If bidding for specified works stops at the minimum price, which remains undisclosed, the "third party" acquires the lot; if bidding exceeds the reserve, the third party splits any profit from its sale with the consignor and with the auction house, the percentage going to each party varying with the deal.<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Tully | first1 = Judd | title = Assurance Policies: Third-Party Guarantees May Reduce Risk and Yield Rewards | date = 22 September 2011 | publisher = [[Louise Blouin Media|Artinfo]] | year = | url = http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/38646/assurance-policies-third-party-guarantees-may-reduce-risk-and-yield-rewards/ | accessdate = 12 November 2012 }}</ref> These proportions, never disclosed to the public, are negotiated before an auction and specified in the contract signed by the auction house and the third party.<ref>Souren Melikian, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/06/arts/06iht-melik6.html Picasso Sells at Record Auction Price], ''The New York Times'', nytimes.com, May 5, 2010.</ref>
=== Online sales === [[File:Teo Spiller net.art.trade (net.art).jpg|thumb|A Screenshot of Teo Spiller's net.art net.art.trade]] In May 1999, [[Teo Spiller]] sold a web art project Megatronix to Ljubljana Municipal Museum, which was by the New York Times announced as the first sell of an [[Internet art]] [[net.art]].<ref>Mirapaul, M [http://partners.nytimes.com/library/tech/99/05/cyber/artsatlarge/13artsatlarge.html "There May Be Money in Internet Art After All"], ''The New York Times, 1999-05-13''</ref>
In 2003, Sotheby's abandoned its partnership with [[eBay]] after it lost millions through its various attempts to sell fine art over the internet.<ref name="duopoly">[http://www.economist.com/node/1612774 Just the two of us - The duopoly in fine-art auctions is weakened but very much alive] ''The Economist'', economist.com, February 27, 2003.</ref>
==What Counts== The [[art sale|art market]] can also be used to understand what “counts” as part of art history. [[Art dealers]] and auctioneers organize material for distribution to collectors. Two of the largest, and oldest, art auction houses are [[Sotheby's]] and [[Christie's]], and each hold frequent sales of great [[antiquities]] and [[Art Object|art objects]].
==Black Market== In addition to upstanding practices, a [[black market]] exists for great art, which is closely tied to [[art theft]] and [[art forgery]]. No auction houses or dealers admit openly to participating in the black market because of its illegality, but exposés suggest widespread problems in the field. Because demand for art objects is high, and security in many parts of the world is low, a thriving trade in [[illicit antiquities]] acquired through [[looting]] also exists. Although the art community nearly universally condemns looting because it results in destruction of [[Archaeological site|archeological sites]], [[looted art]] paradoxically remains omnipresent. Warfare is correlated with such looting, as is demonstrated by the recent [[archaeological looting in Iraq]].

The '''Association of Personal Historians''' ('''APH''') was an international [[non-profit]] [[trade association]] dedicated to developing, supporting and marketing the work of self-employed writers and small businesses who are engaged in preparing print, video, and audio memoirs recording the lives of individuals, families, and communities. Formed in the United States in 1995, it had a global membership of over 650 at its peak,{{cite web| url=http://www.personalhistorians.org/about/about_aph_the_life_story_people.php |website=Association of Personal Historians|title= About APH — The Life Story People'| accessdate=April 23, 2013}} before dissolving in May 2017, reportedly due to "financial constraints and membership trends".[https://truestorieswelltold.com/2017/05/17/when-aph-died-doves-cried/ Sarah White, "When APH Died, Doves Cried", May 17, 2017]. Retrieved 19 May 2017 The APH's mission statement was to "support... its members in recording, preserving and sharing life stories of people, families, communities and organizations around the world."{{cite web| url= http://www.personalhistorians.org/about/vision_mission_goals.php |website=APH|title= Vision, Mission & Goals|accessdate= April 23, 2013}} According to the organization, its members "help other people create personal histories, including memoirs, video tributes, autobiographies, biographies, family histories, heritage cookbooks, community histories, corporate and organizational histories, legacy letters, and ethical wills." ==Concept== Kitty Axelson-Berry founded the organization in 1995.{{cite news| url=http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/news_features/other_stories/multipage/documents/02119922.htm |author=Wright, Chris | title=Ordinary people| work= The Phoenix|location= Boston|date= January 17–24, 2002|accessdate= April 23, 2013}} According to her, "personal historians will not only write, edit, and design your book to your specifications, they'll make it clear from the get-go that the books they produce are meant to be heirlooms rather than potential bestsellers." Increasingly, many personal historians now make use of [[video]] and digital formats.{{cite news| url= http://www.greenwichcitizen.com/news/article/Video-memories-4424734.php |author=Semmes, Anne W. | title=Video Memories| work= Greenwich Citizen| date= April 10, 2013| accessdate= April 23, 2013}} Journalist Chris Wright stated: "The majority of... clients are unabashedly ordinary, and they tell unabashedly mundane tales." Personal historians record and present clients' [[Memory|memories]] and [[Biography|biographies]] as [[books]], in [[Audiobook|audio]] or [[video]] formats, and/or as [[Personal web page|personal websites]].{{cite news| url= http://genealogy.about.com/b/2008/10/19/making-a-living-as-a-personal-historian.htm |author=Powell, Kimberly |title=Making a Living as a Personal Historian|work= About.com|date= October 19, 2008|accessdate= 23 April 2013}} Prices are reported to vary widely, depending on the services offered in each case. The services of personal historians are also used in preparing histories of businesses and other organizations,{{cite news|url= http://www.rockymounttelegram.com/news/pnc-opens-banking-history-exhibit-1842303 |author= Henderson, John| title=PNC opens banking history exhibit|work= Rocky Mount Telegram|date= February 7, 2013|accessdate= April 23, 2013}} and by wealth management companies to help improve bonds with their potential clients.{{cite news| url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/10/us-advisers-history-idUSBRE8790MR20120810 |author=Cummings, Jennifer Hoyt |title= Bonding with clients through their ancestors|work= Reuters.com|date= August 10, 2012|accessdate=April 23, 2013}} Personal historians also provide input to publicly funded [[oral history]] projects.{{cite news| url= http://www.wickedlocal.com/wellesley/news/x2085734989/Local-veteran-recalls-service-in-mountain-division?photo=0#axzz2RD2PqDAd |author=Ryan, Steven |title=Local veteran recalls service in mountain division|work= Wellesley Townsman|date= May 28, 2009|accessdate= April 23, 2013}} Personal historians have been described as comprising "journalists, psychotherapists, social workers, nurses, videographers, gerontologists, and people from other helping or writing professions",{{cite book| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=2gRGXy5VhRMC&pg=PT194&dq=%22personal+historians%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ebV1Udq3A-q90QWbr4DoDw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA |author1=Kunz, John A. |author2=Soltys, Florence Gray |title=Transformational Reminiscence: Life Story Work|publisher= Springer Publishing Company|date= 2007}} as "retired teachers, journalists, genealogists, and therapists..." and as "social workers, journalists and others involved in communications... retirees who want to embark on a second career."{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/12/jobs/12starts.html |author=Olsen, Patricia R. |title=Tales From the Past, Preserved for Families|work= New York Times| date= October 11, 2008|accessdate= April 23, 2013}} In each case they form " [g]enerally a one-person conglomerate of ghostwriter, editor, and publishing house...". Personal history work has been reported to be booming in the US,{{cite news|url=http://www.themonthly.com/shopping-11-07.html |author=Trachten, Rachel |title=Making History: Personal historians document family stories so that future generations can remember them| work= The Monthly |location=East Bay|date=November 2007|accessdate= April 23, 2013}} as "a growing cottage industry of amateurs and professionals eager to preserve the experiences of older generations." Paula Stahel, APH President at the time, said in 2008: "We're seeing an increase both in the number of people who want to do personal historian work and an increase in the number of elders who want to be sure their stories are handed down."{{cite news| url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0527/p17s01-lifp.html |author=Gardner, Marilyn |title=Seniors record stories to preserve personal history|work= Christian Science Monitor|date= May 27, 2008| accessdate= April 23, 2013}} All APH members are expected to abide by the organization's [[code of ethics]].{{cite web|url= http://www.personalhistorians.org/about/code_ethics.php |website= APH|title=Code of ethics| accessdate= April 23, 2013}} Practitioners often have training in skills such as [[interviewing]] techniques, [[desktop publishing]], video and/or audio production, as well as some knowledge of [[geriatrics]] or other disciplines. ==Governance== The APH was governed by an elected, all-volunteer board of directors with overlapping two-year terms. The organization held an annual conference for its members: the 2016 conference was held in Fort Worth, Texas. The 2017 Board of Directors cited decreasing membership and a growing trend towards online networking and collaboration as reasons for dissolution. In a letter to members, the 2017 Board wrote,
"...APH has achieved its purpose many times over, which, as stated in our Bylaws, was to 'advance the profession of helping individuals, organizations, and communities preserve their histories, memories, and life stories.' APH has helped launch more than a thousand personal history businesses, and its members have produced many thousands of personal history works that will be part of our world’s historical record. APH leaves the field at a time when a broader recognition of the importance of saving life stories has emerged and is flourishing—and is widely known and communicated through the work of many other organizations and media outlets. APH has had a significant role in advancing that conversation. And it was our members, as individual practitioners of personal history, who achieved this in countless ways in countless communities, and we know you will continue to do so."{{Cite news|url=http://www.personalhistorians.org|title=Letter to Membership: Dissolution of APH, Inc.|last=APH Board of Directors|first=2017|date=May 9, 2017|work=Constant Contact alluded to under Announcements on this page.|access-date=May 10, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{failed verification|date=May 2017}}
==Resources== Former members of APH and current personal historians are encouraged to use the phrase "personal history" and "personal historian" in search engines in order to find relevant social media groups.
